sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The interface for the Web Content Control is presented as three tabs. The first two tabs, covered in sections and , allow control over blocked and permitted content. The last tab, discussed in , allows administrators to view events.

sect2.title: Block Lists
sect2.para: The Block List tab presents administrators the ability to modify the four major categories of content filtering. Refer to the section for each sub-tab for more detail.

sect3.title: Categories
sect3.para: The Categories tab, as shown in , presents the administrator with the ability to block logical categories of sites. The names of the various categories and a description are presented in the table.

Should a user within the protected network browse to a site which has been selected via the Category tab, they will be presented with an error page. The page will inform the user that their request has been blocked by the Web Content Control Appliance. They will also be told the category (Web Mail, Gambling, etc) of the site in question.

sect3.title: URLs
sect3.para: The block list of URLs is shown in

The URL block list is initialy empty. When adding a new entry, you enter a URL which encompases an exact match or any URLs matching that prefix (see for more details on URL matching). The category column can contain any category of your choosing (it does not have to correspond to the predefined categories discussed in ).

sect3.title: MIME Types
sect3.para: The MIME Types tab lets administrators block the downloading of content by MIME type. The interface for the MIME Types tab is shown in .
As shown in , most of the common MIME types have already been entered into the list. By default, they are not being blocked. To cause a particular MIME Type to be blocked, check the block box.

sect3.title: File Extensions
sect3.para: The File Extensions Tab, as shown in , allows Administrators to cause the download of files to be blocked based on file extension (e.g. .exe).
As shown in , many common file extensions have already been entered into the list. By default, they are not being blocked. To cause files of a given extension to be blocked, check the block box.

sect2.title: Pass Lists
sect2.para: As discussed in , the Web Content Control Appliance offers several ways to block inappropriate or malicious traffic from entering your protected network. However, there may be circumstances where you need to bypass these guards for an individual within your company, or a site outside your network.

For this reason, the Pass Lists have been created. When traffic is found to match an entry in one of the pass lists, it is not filtered. Passes can be created for various sites, as discussed in , or for individual machines within the protected network as discussed in

The category column can contain any category of your choosing (it does not have to correspond to the predefined categories discussed in ).

sect3.title: Clients
sect3.para: The lets Administrators define sites outside the protected network which will not receive filtering. The Clients Tab lets Administrators define machines within the protected network whose requests will not be filtered. The interface for the client pass list is shown in .

The list shown in is initialy empty. As new entries are made, administrators must enter client IP address. The format of client IP address is either in Simple IP Address or Network/Netmask format. Note that the category field is only for administrator reference - it need not match up with the predefined categories discussed in .

The Events Tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The action describes the action which the ⪚ took on the web request. client shows the IP address of the client who made the request.

question.para: Why is there both blocking by MIME Type and File Extension?

answer.para: In an ideal world, both pieces of information would always be present for every web request. However, some sites use incorrect content types or extensions. Also, the behavior of operating systems (Windows vs. Mac) is different when given only file extension or content type. To be safe, both lists should be used.
